Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ultra Fine Particle Deposition onto Vegetated Surfaces Situated on Complex Topography: From Leaf to Landscape
Award.AbstractNarration:
Vegetated surfaces produce and can serve as a sink for ultrafine particles (UFP) that can affect local climate and air-quality. This work examines the interaction of the forest canopy with the UFP under realistic conditions to develop methods to predict the efficacy of forests as UFP sinks. The findings inform how vegetation effects ecosystem services, climate and air quality. It also provide and opportunity to scrub pollution from rapidly growing nano-particle products in urban areas.

Forests produce particles that play an important but ill-understood role in the radiative balance and composition of the atmosphere. The proposal focuses on the quantification of Ultra-fine particles (UFP) fluxes from vegetation canopies that are controlled by complex dynamical and reactive processes using first principles. Their up scaling method resolves (1) the effects of leaf morphology (2) flows within the a canopy and on landscape scales and (3) effects of large scale topography. The project will use laboratory and field experiments over a range of scales to understand fundamental questions such as (1) How does foliage size, shape and structure impact UFP collection? (2) How does the UFP deposition velocity vary within the canopy? (3) Can we reliably upscale these UFP fluxes for complex topography? This project should enable the development of next generation canopy models to treat couplings and chemical feedbacks between ecosystems and the atmosphere.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As part of this project we have developed a new numerical approach to simulate dry deposition of ultrafine particles (UFP) onto forests. This is the first model capable of representing the effects of particle size, vegetation characteristics (total leaf area index, its vertical distribution, leaf morphology, etc.), and its underlying topography on the deposition rates of UFP. Using this model, we identified key parameters governing UFP deposition efficiency over flat and complex topography, and applied this model to a case study in the Amazon forest. We also found that even very gentle topography, when covered by a dense forest, modifies the winds in a dramatic way, with important consequences for the transport of particles and gases. In particular, we found that most of the transport of gases and particles emitted within the forest occurs over fairly small regions, whose position is determined mostly be the topography. These regions act as chimneys of the forest, as gases emitted within the forest converge towards them inside the forest and then are transported out. Our findings have broad implications for observational and modeling studies of forest-gas exchanges, including chemically active gases (such as biogenic volatile organic compounds), carbon dioxide and water vapor. This finding has important implications to how we measure exchanges of reactive gases and particles over forests, impacting optimal siting of measurement stations and interpretation of observations. It also points to a major limitation inherent to all existing models of gas and particle deposition onto vegetation, as these are based on flat terrain assumptions.
